demos.template:
# Action-Oriented Summary & Next Steps

## 1) One-line summary
- Core outcome or decision:
- Context (1–2 sentences):

## 2) Key objectives
- Objective 1 (specific, measurable):
- Objective 2 (specific, measurable):
- Timeline overview:

## 3) Immediate next steps (top priority)
- Action 1 — Owner — Due date — Status — Effort/priority
- Action 2 — Owner — Due date — Status — Effort/priority
- Action 3 — Owner — Due date — Status — Effort/priority

## 4) Short-term plan (this week → 1 month)
- Milestone A
  - Actions: 
    - Action — Owner — Due date
  - Success criteria:
- Milestone B
  - Actions:
    - Action — Owner — Due date
  - Success criteria:

## 5) Mid-term plan (1–3 months)
- Major deliverables:
  - Deliverable — Owner — Target date — Dependencies
- Risks & mitigations:
  - Risk — Likelihood/impact — Mitigation owner/action

## 6) Decisions required (who/what/when)
- Decision 1 — Decision owner — Deadline — Options considered
- Decision 2 — Decision owner — Deadline — Options considered

## 7) Dependencies & constraints
- External dependencies (teams/vendors) — Impact if delayed
- Internal constraints (budget, headcount, tech) — Notes

## 8) Success metrics & monitoring
- Primary metric(s):
- Targets and baseline:
- Reporting cadence and owner:

## 9) Communication & stakeholder plan
- Who to update — Frequency — Channel — Owner
- Key message for next update:

## 10) Resources / budget needs
- Resource or budget item — Amount/effort — Owner — Approval needed by:

## 11) Follow-up cadence & review
- Next review date:
- Participants:
- Intended agenda items:

## 12) Notes & references
- Relevant docs/links:
- Open issues / questions:

Template usage tip:
- For each action, always specify: Action description — Assigned owner — Concrete due date — Clear success criteria — Current status.
- Prioritize 3–5 immediate next steps; keep everything else aligned to those actions.

# Consulting Summary — Issues & Recommendations

## 1. Executive summary
- Purpose of engagement
- Top 3 issues (one-line each)
- Top 3 recommended actions (one-line each)
- Expected impact (high-level: cost, revenue, risk reduction, timeline)

## 2. Scope & objectives
- Scope (business units, processes, systems, timeframe)
- Primary objectives and success criteria
- Out-of-scope items (if any)

## 3. Approach & data sources
- Methods used (interviews, data analysis, process mapping, workshops)
- Key data sources and documents reviewed
- Assumptions and limitations

## 4. Key issues (structured)
For each issue include:
- Issue title
- Brief description (what is happening)
- Evidence (data points, examples)
- Root cause(s)
- Business impact (quantitative where possible: cost, revenue, cycle time, risk exposure)
- Priority (Critical / High / Medium / Low)

Example categories:
- Strategic alignment
- Operations & process inefficiencies
- Financial performance / cost drivers
- Technology & systems (integration, legacy)
- People & organizational design
- Customer experience & market positioning
- Compliance & regulatory risk
- Data & analytics capability

## 5. Prioritization framework
- Criteria used (impact, urgency, ease-of-implementation, regulatory need)
- Priority buckets:
  - Critical: must fix now (high impact, high risk)
  - High: important within next 3–9 months
  - Medium: 9–18 months
  - Low: monitor or long-term
- Suggested quick ranking table (Issue | Priority | Rationale)

## 6. Recommendations (by timeframe & priority)
For each recommendation include:
- Recommendation title and objective
- Summary of action steps
- Owner / accountable party
- Estimated time to implement
- Estimated effort & cost (low/medium/high or $)
- Dependencies & prerequisites
- Success metrics / KPIs
- Risk & mitigation

Group recommendations:
- Quick wins (0–3 months): low effort, immediate benefit
- Medium-term (3–9 months): require moderate effort/resources
- Long-term (9+ months): transformational initiatives, capital investment

Sample recommendation entry:
- Recommendation: Simplify order-to-cash workflow
  - Objective: Reduce order processing time by 40%
  - Actions: process mapping, automation of manual steps, train staff
  - Owner: Head of Ops
  - Timeline: 3 months
  - Cost: $XXk
  - KPI: average processing time, error rate, DSO
  - Risk: integration delays → Mitigation: phased pilot

## 7. Implementation roadmap (high-level)
- Phased timeline with milestones (Phase 0: planning & governance; Phase 1: quick wins; Phase 2: scale; Phase 3: embed & optimize)
- Key milestones and gating criteria
- Suggested sequencing (dependencies highlighted)
- Example Gantt-like outline (quarterly or monthly milestones)

## 8. Governance & resourcing
- Recommended governance model (steering committee, working groups)
- Roles & responsibilities (RACI summary)
- Resource requirements (FTEs, contractor, budget)
- External vendors or systems required

## 9. KPIs, reporting & monitoring
- Core KPIs to measure success (financial, operational, customer)
- Dashboard/reporting cadence (weekly, monthly, quarterly)
- Who receives which reports
- Mechanism for continuous improvement

## 10. Risks & mitigation plan
- Key implementation risks (technical, people, financial, market)
- Mitigation actions and contingency plans
- Residual risk assessment

## 11. Change management & communications
- Stakeholder map and impact analysis
- Key messages per stakeholder group
- Training and adoption plan
- Communication timeline & channels

## 12. Estimated benefits & ROI
- Quantified benefits (cost savings, revenue uplift, efficiency gains)
- One-page financial summary: investment vs. annualized benefit vs. payback period
- Non-financial benefits (risk reduction, customer satisfaction)

## 13. Next steps & immediate asks
- Decisions required (approve budget, assign owner, pilot approval)
- Immediate actions for the next 30/60/90 days
- Contact points and governance setup date

## 14. Appendices / supporting materials
- Detailed issue analyses (charts, tables)
- Data extracts and assumptions
- Process maps and current-state diagrams
- Detailed cost estimates and vendor assessments
- Glossary of terms

## Templates & quick artifacts to include
- Issue template (to fill for each problem)
  - Title:
  - Description:
  - Evidence:
  - Root cause:
  - Impact:
  - Priority:
- Recommendation / Action-tracking table (columns to use)
  - ID | Recommendation | Owner | Priority | Start | Target completion | Effort/Cost | KPI | Status | Notes

## Suggested deliverables for final pack
- 2-page Executive summary
- Full issue & recommendation report (10–25 pages depending on depth)
- Implementation roadmap (visual)
- Financial model / ROI sheet (spreadsheet)
- Stakeholder communications plan
- Action tracker (living document)

## Closing note
- Immediate recommended next step (one-sentence call to action)
- Proposed date for decision / workshop to align on priorities

# Forschungsmeeting — Hypothesen & Schlussfolgerungen

## 1. Meeting-Infos
- Datum:
- Uhrzeit:
- Ort / Link:
- Dauer:
- Moderator / Protokollant:

## 2. Ziel des Meetings
- Kurzbeschreibung der Hauptziele (z. B. Hypothesen finalisieren, Analyse planen, Schlussfolgerungen abstimmen)

## 3. Teilnehmer
- Namen & Rollen
- Zuständigkeiten (wer entscheidet, wer liefert Daten/Analysen)

## 4. Hintergrund & Kontext
- Forschungsfrage(n) / Problemstellung:
- Relevante Vorbefunde / Literaturhinweise:
- Bisherige Ergebnisse / Status (kurz):

## 5. Forschungsfragen und Hypothesen
- Forschungsfrage 1:
  - Hypothese 1 (präzise, testbar):
    - Begründung / theoretische Grundlage:
    - Operationalisierung (Variablen, Messgrößen):
    - Erwartetes Muster (Richtung, Effektgröße, Bedingung):
  - Hypothese 2 (falls vorhanden): (gleiches Schema)
- Forschungsfrage 2: (analog)

## 6. Analyse- und Prüfplan
- Datensatz(en) / Stichprobe:
- Messinstrumente / Variablenliste:
- Geplante Analysen / Tests (z. B. t-Test, ANOVA, Regression, Bayessche Analyse):
- Signifikanz- / Entscheidskriterien (alpha, Konfidenzintervalle, Bayes-Faktoren):
- Sensitivitätsanalysen / Robustheitschecks:
- Benötigte Voraussetzungen (z. B. Normalverteilung, Homoskedastizität) und Tests dafür:

## 7. Erwartete Ergebnisse & alternative Szenarien
- Szenario A (Hypothese bestätigt): Konsequenzen für Theorie / Praxis
- Szenario B (keine Effekte): Interpretation & mögliche Ursachen
- Szenario C (entgegengesetzte Effekte): Interpretation & Folgeschritte

## 8. Schlussfolgerungen (zu protokollieren)
- Zusammenfassung der Schlussfolgerungen aus den präsentierten/analysierten Ergebnissen:
- Grad der Evidenz für jede Hypothese (stark / moderat / schwach / nicht unterstützt):
- Offene Fragen, die weiter untersucht werden müssen:

## 9. Implikationen & Empfehlungen
- Theoretische Implikationen:
- Methodische Empfehlungen für Folgestudien:
- Praktische / politische Empfehlungen (falls zutreffend):

## 10. Entscheidungen & nächste Schritte
- Beschlüsse während des Meetings:
- Konkrete Action Items:
  - Aufgabe:
  - Verantwortlich:
  - Frist:
- Benötigte Ressourcen / Unterstützung:

## 11. Zeitplan / Milestones
- Kurzfristige Meilensteine (nächste 2–4 Wochen):
- Mittelfristige Meilensteine (nächste 3–6 Monate):

## 12. Risiken, Limitationen & Qualitätskontrolle
- Bekannte Limitationen (Stichprobe, Messungen, Confounder):
- Risiken für Validität / Generalisierbarkeit:
- Maßnahmen zur Qualitätskontrolle (Pre-registrierung, Code-Review, Replikationscheck):

## 13. Anhang / Referenzen
- Wichtige Literatur:
- Verwendete Datendefinitionen / Codebooks:
- Links zu Daten / Analyse-Skripten:
- Protokoll-Template für detaillierte Ergebnisaufzeichnung

demos.requirements: 给患者的英文诊断报告总结，用词简单
demos.template:
# Patient Diagnostic Summary

- Patient: [Name]
- Date: [Date]
- Provider: [Doctor / Clinic]
- Main diagnosis: [Short diagnosis]

## Short summary
- In one sentence: [Brief simple sentence about the diagnosis]
- Key finding(s): 
  - [Finding 1]
  - [Finding 2]

## What this means (simple words)
- [Finding 1] means: [Simple explanation]
- [Finding 2] means: [Simple explanation]
- Overall: [One-line plain meaning for the patient]

## Tests done
- [Test name] — result: [normal / abnormal / numeric value]
- [Test name] — result: [normal / abnormal / numeric value]

## Treatment and plan
- Medicines: 
  - [Medicine name] — dose: [dose], how often: [times/day]
- Procedures or therapy:
  - [Procedure or therapy], when: [date or "as soon as possible"]
- Lifestyle advice:
  - [Simple instruction, e.g., "Rest", "Low salt diet", "Light exercise"]

## Follow-up
- Next visit: [date or time frame, e.g., "in 2 weeks"]
- Tests to repeat: [Test name] — when: [time frame]

## When to get help right away
- Go to ER or call us if you have:
  - [Worse symptom 1, e.g., "severe chest pain"]
  - [Worse symptom 2, e.g., "difficulty breathing"]
  - [Worse symptom 3, e.g., "high fever over 39°C"]

## Contacts
- Clinic phone: [phone number]
- After-hours: [phone number / instructions]

## Questions
- If you have questions, please ask your doctor or nurse.
- Write down symptoms and medicines to bring to your next visit.

signature.instructions:
You are a concise, professional meeting‑template writer whose job is to produce short, scannable, reusable summary/meeting‑note templates (not filled summaries). Given a single "requirements" string, generate only a ready‑to‑use template that follows the user's language, audience, domain, tone/register, and any explicit format request.

Rules:
1. Persona & purpose: You are a professional meeting‑notes/template author focused on extreme concision, scannability, and actionability. Output must be a template with clear placeholders (do not invent facts).
2. Language & tone: Detect the language from an explicit lang: tag or from the requirements text. Write the entire template in that language. Match the requested tone/register (e.g., "formal", "friendly", "technical", "executive").
3. Format defaults: If the user does not specify formatting, produce minimal Markdown using headers (#, ##) and bullet points. Avoid heavy formatting (no tables, code blocks, or long prose) unless the user asks. Use plain, short lines and consistent placeholder conventions like [Owner], [Due date], [Project], [Link].
4. Required structure (unless user requests a different structure): 
   - Top: one‑line TL;DR (single sentence).
   - Scannable sections with short headers and bullets. Include, at minimum: Key objectives, Immediate next steps (prioritized; 3–5 items), Decisions required, Dependencies & constraints, Success metrics & monitoring, Communication/stakeholder plan, Resources/budget needs, Follow-up cadence & review, Notes & references.
   - Each action item must include explicit placeholders for: Action — Owner — Due date — Success criteria — Status.
5. Action orientation & prioritization: Put top priority items first. Mark priority (P0/P1/P2 or High/Medium/Low) and limit "Immediate next steps" to 3–5 items. Provide place for owners and deadlines.
6. Avoid inventing facts: If the requirements lack concrete details, use clear placeholders (e.g., [Decision owner], [Target date], [Metric name]) rather than fabricating values. Do NOT fill in hypothetical specifics.
7. Audience & domain adaptation: Tailor section names and examples to the stated audience (e.g., "Executive summary" for execs, "Tech notes" for engineers) and domain (consulting, research, product). If user requests a specific template type (consulting, research meeting, action plan), adapt headings and content accordingly.
8. Concision constraints: Keep templates compact and scannable — short headers, concise bullet lines, and no explanatory paragraphs. Do not include extra instructions or meta commentary.
9. Output only: Return only the template text (no preface, no postface, no commentary).

If the requirements include examples or request a different formatting style, follow that precisely. If ambiguous, default to Markdown headers and bullets.

Produce the template now based strictly on the provided requirements input.

fields.description: User input containing either keywords or a descriptive paragraph
By default, generate a structured outline using Markdown headers (#, ##) and bullet points unless the user explicitly specifies alternative formatting requirements.
